nodename.name: nodename
nodename.description: The name of the system that the agent is running on as given by the login prompt.

cpu.name: cpu
cpu.description: The CPU type of the system that the agent is running on (e.g. sun4c, sun4m).

memory.name: memory
memory.description: The amount of memory in 1024 byte units contained in the system.

hostid.name: hostid
hostid.description: The hostid number that resides on the mother board of the system that the agent is running on. The hostid is unique across all machines manufactured by the same vendor.

osver.name: osver
osver.description: The operating system version of the system that the agent resides (e.g. 7). Each time a new kernel is re-linked for a given kernel configuration file, this number is incremented.

osrel.name: osrel
osrel.description: The operating system release of the system that the agent resides (e.g. 4.1.3).

devTable.name: devTable
devTable.description: This table describes all mounted file systems on the system that the agent resides.

devTableEntry.name: devTableEntry
devTableEntry.description: An entry in the device table.

devIndex.name: devIndex
devIndex.description: This object does not describe the mounted device. Its sole purpose is to indicate the row instance. The instance is derived from the index number from the mounted file systems file.

devDevice.name: devDevice
devDevice.description: The device name (e.g. /dev/sd0a) corresponding to the mounted file system. For example, the '/' file system is commonly mounted from the device '/dev/sd0a'. For network file systems, the value corresponds to the remote host and remote file system name (e.g. emptech:/usr/local).

devMntPt.name: devMntPt
devMntPt.description: The mount point or path name in the local file system where the device is mounted (e.g. /home).

devBsize.name: devBsize
devBsize.description: The block size of the mounted device in bytes. File systems and disk devices generally allocate data in fixed size 'blocks' generally referred to as the device's block size. Common block sizes are 1024 (1K) and 2048 (2K) bytes.

devTblks.name: devTblks
devTblks.description: The total number of blocks contained in the mounted device.

devFblks.name: devFblks
devFblks.description: The total number of free or unallocated blocks in the mounted device.

devTfiles.name: devTfiles
devTfiles.description: Each disk device and file system allocates a fixed, maximum number of files that can be written to the device. The value of this object indicates the maximum number of files that can be written to this device.

devFfiles.name: devFfiles
devFfiles.description: The number of free or unallocated files that can be created on this device.

devMaxNameLen.name: devMaxNameLen
devMaxNameLen.description: The maximum file name length that this mounted device supports. If no fixed limit exists, 0 is returned.

devType.name: devType
devType.description: The type of the mounted device. If this underlying device does not support feature, 0 is returned.

devFsid.name: devFsid
devFsid.description: The (possibly unique) file system ID of the mounted device. V.4 systems support its uniqueness while SunOS does not. For devices or operating systems not supporting this object, the object instance identifier is returned instead.

devFstr.name: devFstr
devFstr.description: Some devices support a description string. If supported by the underlying device and operating system, that device specific description string is returned. If not supported, the string 'Not supported' is returned. An example description string may be 'User home directories'.

devUnmount.name: devUnmount
devUnmount.description: Writing a delete(1) to this object causes the agent to unmount this device and remove its entry from the mounted file system table. Writing any other value to this object will cause no action to be taken by the agent.

devCapacity.name: devCapacity
devCapacity.description: The percentage of the device's total capacity in use.

devInodeCapacity.name: devInodeCapacity
devInodeCapacity.description: The percentage of the device's total file capacity (inodes) in use. File systems often place an upper bound on the number of files that can be created on a filesystem. This value indicates the percentage of total possible files that are in use. Many times, NFS clients cannot determine this value for remotely mounted filesystems; in that case, 0 is returned.

agentVersion.name: agentVersion
agentVersion.description: The agent's description and software version number (e.g 'Concord . . . Ver 4.1').

maxProcs.name: maxProcs
maxProcs.description: Maximum number of slots in the system process table or simply, the maximum number of processes that may run at any one time on the system.

serialNumber.name: serialNumber
serialNumber.description: The system's serial number. This number is different from the system's hostid value; it should be unique across all platforms manufactured by the same vendor.

romVersion.name: romVersion
romVersion.description: The system's ROM version number (e.g 2.6). Different versions of ROM often support different commands and options. Knowing the system's ROM version number is often helpful in debugging operating system problems.

numCPU.name: numCPU
numCPU.description: The number of CPUs contained within this host.

clockHZ.name: clockHZ
clockHZ.description: The system's clock or 'tick' rate in HZ. This is the rate at operating system is given regularly, periodic interrupts in order to handle I/O, schedule processes, etc. This value should not be confused with the CPU clock speed which is generally on the order mega-hertz.

kernelVers.name: kernelVers
kernelVers.description: The kernel version; This description string is compiled into the kernel at kernel build time and is generally used to convey information about its functionality, patch level, or administrative domain.

virtualMem.name: virtualMem
virtualMem.description: The amount of virtual memory in 1024 byte units (KBytes).

maxInode.name: maxInode
maxInode.description: Maximum number of in core file inodes allocated by this host. An inode is a data structure used by a file system to describe a file. Part of it is cached in memory (in core) while the other is stored on disk; the kernel allocates a fixed amount of these structures at kernel boot time for use with file I/O.

maxFiles.name: maxFiles
maxFiles.description: Maximum number of open files the system can support at any one time. The kernel pre-allocates, at kernel boot time, a table of structures for file I/O. If the kernel does not place any upper bound (e.g. Solaris 2.x), than 0 is returned.

maxClist.name: maxClist
maxClist.description: The maximum number of 'clist' structures allocated by the kernel. Line disciplines, like terminals, manipulate data on 'clists' which are essentially linked-lists of data heading to and from terminal or serial devices. If the underlying operating system does not utilize 'clists', then 0 is returned.

maxMemPerProc.name: maxMemPerProc
maxMemPerProc.description: Maximum memory per process in KBytes. Operating systems often set an upper limit on the amount of memory a process may use. If the underlying operating system does not set such a limit, than 0 is returned.

totalSwap.name: totalSwap
totalSwap.description: Total system swap space in KBytes. Swap is a region on secondary storage (primarily disks) that is used for swapping and paging. Swapping is a memory management policy in which entire processes are written to secondary storage when memory is in short supply. When a process begins, all its pages are in virtual memory; only those pages actively being used are brought in from disk or swap.

openMaxPerProc.name: openMaxPerProc
openMaxPerProc.description: Maximum number of open files per process. Each process is generally given a limit on the maximum number of files it may have open at any one time. If the operating system does not impose such limits, the value 0 is returned.

posixJobCtrl.name: posixJobCtrl
posixJobCtrl.description: Boolean variable indicating if Posix Job Control supported. POSIX, an IEEE standard, defines a portable, open interface to operating systems. Part of the specification includes the definition of support for advanced job control. This value indicates whether the system supports POSIX-style job control.

posixVersion.name: posixVersion
posixVersion.description: The POSIX version number supported by host operating system. As new versions of POSIX are released, it may be important to monitor which host supports which version of the POSIX standard.

pageSize.name: pageSize
pageSize.description: This object returns the number of bytes in a page; a 'page' is the fixed size unit of measurement when dealing with both virtual and physical memory. Page granularity is the granularity of many of the memory statistics and objects throughout the Concord MIB. This page size is an operating system page size and may not correspond to the underlying hardware page size.

wordSize.name: wordSize
wordSize.description: This object returns the kernel word size. For example, if Solaris is booted with a 64 bit kernel, this object would return 64. If Solaris is booted with a 32 bit kernel, this object would return 32. This object is available in SystemEDGE 4.1 and higher.

rootName.name: rootName
rootName.description: The Device and partition (e.g. sd0a) that the root filesystem is mounted from.

rootBlocks.name: rootBlocks
rootBlocks.description: The total number of blocks contained in the root filesystem. The value 0 is returned if unknown.

dumpName.name: dumpName
dumpName.description: The device and partition (e.g. sd0b) that the dump filesystem is mounted from. 'Dump' is a area of secondary storage reserved by the operating system so that it may write diagnostic information in the event of a kernel crash.

dumpFSType.name: dumpFSType
dumpFSType.description: The dump filesystem type (e.g. spec). Dump is generally not a 'normal' file system like UFS, 4.2, etc.

dumpBlocks.name: dumpBlocks
dumpBlocks.description: The total number of blocks contained in the dump filesystem.

swapName.name: swapName
swapName.description: The device and partition (e.g. sd0b) that serves as swap space for the running kernel.

swapFSType.name: swapFSType
swapFSType.description: The swap filesystem type (e.g. spec). Swap space is not generally a typical file system like UFS, 4.2, etc.

swapSize.name: swapSize
swapSize.description: The total number of blocks contained in the kernel's swap area.

maxmsgSize.name: maxmsgSize
maxmsgSize.description: The maximum Streams message size in bytes. Streams often places a limit on the size of an individual message. If the underlying system does not place such a limit, 0 is returned.

maxNumPush.name: maxNumPush
maxNumPush.description: Maximum number of Streams modules that may be 'pushed' onto an individual stream at any one time. If the underlying system does not define such a limit, 0 is returned.

streamUse.name: streamUse
streamUse.description: Current number of open 'streams' in the system. Operating systems often place a limit on the number of streams that may be in use at any one time. Monitoring this variable and streamMax can indicate if additional streams should be configured.

streamMaxs.name: streamMaxs
streamMaxs.description: The largest number of open 'streams' recorded by the system. This value represents a 'high-water' mark.

streamFails.name: streamFails
streamFails.description: The number of 'stream' allocation failures that have occurred. Monitoring the streamUse, streamMax, and streamFail variables can help determine if the Streams subsystem is properly configured.

queueUse.name: queueUse
queueUse.description: Number of Streams queues currently in use by the system. Streams are composed of queues, one for each direction of data flow. The value of this variable indicates the number of queue data structures currently in use.

queueMaxs.name: queueMaxs
queueMaxs.description: The largest number of open 'streams' recorded by the system. This value represents the 'high-water' mark.

queueFails.name: queueFails
queueFails.description: The number of Streams queue allocation failures. Monitoring the queueUse, queueMax, and queueFail variables can help determine if the Streams subsystem is properly configured.

mblockUse.name: mblockUse
mblockUse.description: The number of Streams message blocks currently in use. Streams messages are composed of message-blocks in a linked-list. The value of this variable indicates how many of the systems message blocks are in use.

mblockMaxs.name: mblockMaxs
mblockMaxs.description: The largest number of Streams message blocks in use at any one time. This value represents a 'high-water' mark.

mblockFails.name: mblockFails
mblockFails.description: The number of Streams message block allocation failures. Monitoring the mblockUse, mblockMax, and mblockFail variables can help determine if the Streams subsystem is properly configured.

dblockUse.name: dblockUse
dblockUse.description: The number of Streams data blocks currently in use. Message data is stored in data-blocks; the value of this variable indicates how many of the data-blocks are currently in use.

dblockMaxs.name: dblockMaxs
dblockMaxs.description: The largest number of Streams data blocks in use at any one time. This value represents a 'high-water' mark.

dblockFails.name: dblockFails
dblockFails.description: The number of Streams data block allocation failures. Monitoring the dblockUse, dblockMax, and dblockFail variables can help determine if the Streams subsystem is properly configured.

systemEdgeUptime.name: systemEdgeUptime
systemEdgeUptime.description: The SystemEDGE agent's uptime. Use for uptime calculations with variables in the Concord MIB. This is the same value as returned by the uptime value in MIB2. However, on some platforms (e.g. NT), that value is not returned by SystemEDGE and is thus inconsistent with the SystemEDGE uptime.

sysedgeLicenseString.name: sysedgeLicenseString
sysedgeLicenseString.description: This object is used in conjunction Concord's auto-licensing and remote licensing facility starting in SystemEDGE 4.0.

sysedgeLicenseKey.name: sysedgeLicenseKey
sysedgeLicenseKey.description: This object is used in conjunction Concord's auto-licensing and remote licensing facility starting in SystemEDGE 4.0.

sysedgeMode.name: sysedgeMode
sysedgeMode.description: This object indicates if SystemEDGE is in full-mode or restricted-mode. Restricted-mode is entered, when SystemEDGE 4.0 and higher, fails to find a valid license. Once a valid license has been allocated and set, SystemEDGE will then transition to fullMode(1)

systemTimeZone.name: systemTimeZone
systemTimeZone.description: The timezone this system is in obtained via TZ environment variable (UNIX) or NT win32 call. If SystemEDGE is unable to determine the timezone, 'unknown' is returned. This value is operating-system depdendent in that each OS often has slightly different names for same timezone.

sysedgeAddressList.name: sysedgeAddressList
sysedgeAddressList.description: The space-separated list of up to 5 past IP addresses that this system was configured for. This MIB object, when used with the addrChangeTrap, is useful to pollers trying to poll client machines whose addresses change due to DHCP or with mobile systems or those whose configuration changes over time. Addresses are ordered with most-recently from most-recently used to least-recently used (left to right).

sysedgeFQDN.name: sysedgeFQDN
sysedgeFQDN.description: The system's fully qualified domain name (FQDN); this MIB object is a duplicate of mib-2.system.sysName but is repeated here for platform consistency (e.g. NT vs. UNIX).

sysedgeConfProfile.name: sysedgeConfProfile
sysedgeConfProfile.description: A space-separated list of configuration profile names currently configured in SystemEDGE. Configuration profiles are managed by AdvantEDGE View; AdvantEDGE View uses this MIB object to store, with each agent, which profiles are currently deployed to that agent. Writing to or modifying this variable outside of AdvantEDGE View is strongly discouraged. This MIB variable should not contain single nor double quotations.

sysedgeInstallDir.name: sysedgeInstallDir
sysedgeInstallDir.description: The directory where the SystemEDGE distribution is installed (e.g. c:\sysedge or /opt/EMPsysedge). One can use this value to help configure actions, extensions, etc.

sysedgePluginList.name: sysedgePluginList
sysedgePluginList.description: A comma-separated list of plugins that are currently loaded into SystemEDGE. Management software can use this MIB object to determine installation and upgrade requirements. If no plugins are loaded, a zero-length string is returned.

userTable.name: userTable
userTable.description: Table describing defined users of the node which the agent resides on. Normally, the list of valid users is stored in the /etc/passwd file; on systems which run NIS or NIS+, this table represents both users in the /etc/passwd file and in the NIS passwd file.

userEntry.name: userEntry
userEntry.description: An entry in the table describing defined users.

userIndex.name: userIndex
userIndex.description: The instance of the userEntry object, derived from its index number in the password file.

userLoginID.name: userLoginID
userLoginID.description: The user's login ID which is normally given to the system's login prompt (e.g. root).

userPasswd.name: userPasswd
userPasswd.description: The user's encrypted password. Users without passwords have an '*' in this field.

userName.name: userName
userName.description: The user's real life name (e.g. John Doe).

userHomeDir.name: userHomeDir
userHomeDir.description: The user's home directory when that user logs in (e.g. /home/john).

groupTable.name: groupTable
groupTable.description: Table describing defined groups on node that agent resides. Normally the list of valid user groups is stored in the file /etc/group. On systems running NIS or NIS+, this table represents valid groups in /etc/group and in the NIS group file.

groupEntry.name: groupEntry
groupEntry.description: Entry in table describing valid groups.

groupIndex.name: groupIndex
groupIndex.description: The instance of the groupEntry object, derived from its index in the groups file.

groupName.name: groupName
groupName.description: The name of the group (e.g. wheel).

groupPasswd.name: groupPasswd
groupPasswd.description: The encrypted password for the group. Groups without passwords have an '*' in this field.

processTable.name: processTable
processTable.description: Table describing currently running processes on the node which the SNMP agent resides.

processEntry.name: processEntry
processEntry.description: Each entry in the process table represents a single running process. Because the SNMP standard does not allow tables to be indexed with the value 0, and because PID 0 is valid on many UNIX and NT systems, SystemEDGE really indexes the processTable with processID+1. That is, process with PID 0 is contained at table index 1.

processID.name: processID
processID.description: The unique process ID (e.g. 0). The value of this object also serves as the instance of the processEntry object.

processName.name: processName
processName.description: The name of the running process (e.g. swapper).

processState.name: processState
processState.description: The process state is operating system dependent. Possible states (for SunOS 4.1.3) include sleeping(1), waiting(2), running (3), idle (4), zombie (5), stopped(6), unknown(7). This MIB object should be deprecated in favor of processStateStr which is portable and standard across all platforms. processState values are platform specific and thus harder to handle in platform-independent manner.

processNice.name: processNice
processNice.description: The 'nice' value of the process which can be modified to give a process greater or lesser priority over other processes. The 'nice' value reflects the level of priority that the running process has; the higher the value, the lower the priority the process has.

processFlags.name: processFlags
processFlags.description: The process flags; flags are operating system dependent and are generally documented in system header files.

processUID.name: processUID
processUID.description: The process owner's user ID (e.g. 0 for root).

processGID.name: processGID
processGID.description: The process owner's group ID (e.g. 0 for wheel).

processKill.name: processKill
processKill.description: This object represents a signal that can be sent to the running process. When accessed with GET or GetNext, a 0 is returned. When a valid signal value is written, the agent sends that signal to the corresponding process. To kill or delete a process from the process table, the value corresponding to SIGKILL(9) should be written to this object. Signals are defined in a system dependent manner and are usually defined in system header files and manual pages.

processMEM.name: processMEM
processMEM.description: The percentage (0-100) of real memory used by this process.

processSize.name: processSize
processSize.description: The combined size of the text, data and stack segments in KBytes. Processes are normally broken into segments including those for text (or program), data, and stack. This variable indicates how large the variable size portion of a process is. Monitoring this value can help determine the health of a process.

processRSS.name: processRSS
processRSS.description: Real memory (resident set) size of the process in kilobytes. This value indicates how many bytes are held by a process.

processTime.name: processTime
processTime.description: This process' accumulated CPU time in seconds.

processNumThreads.name: processNumThreads
processNumThreads.description: The number of threads executing within this process. Note, on some systems, the operating system may be un-aware of user-level threads executing within the process. This object reflects the number of threads executing within the process that the operating system is aware of.

processInBlks.name: processInBlks
processInBlks.description: The number of blocks of data input by the process.

processOutBlks.name: processOutBlks
processOutBlks.description: The number of blocks of data output by the process.

processMsgsSent.name: processMsgsSent
processMsgsSent.description: The number of messages sent by the process.

processMsgsRecv.name: processMsgsRecv
processMsgsRecv.description: The number of messages received by the process.

processSysCalls.name: processSysCalls
processSysCalls.description: The number of system calls invoked by this process.

processMinorPgFlts.name: processMinorPgFlts
processMinorPgFlts.description: The number of minor page faults incurred by this process. Minor faults do not require I/O to retrieve the page.

processMajorPgFlts.name: processMajorPgFlts
processMajorPgFlts.description: The number of major page faults incurred by this process. Major faults require I/O to retrieve the page.

processNumSwaps.name: processNumSwaps
processNumSwaps.description: The number of times this process has been swapped.

processVolCtx.name: processVolCtx
processVolCtx.description: The number of voluntary context switches incurred by this process. Voluntary context switches occur when the processor 'voluntary' gives up the CPU (e.g. waiting on I/O.)

processInvolCtx.name: processInvolCtx
processInvolCtx.description: The number of involuntary context switches incurred by this process. An involuntary context switch occurs when the process has executed for the duration of its time quantum and is switched out by the process scheduler.

processArgs.name: processArgs
processArgs.description: The parameters supplied to this process when it was initially started.

processStartTime.name: processStartTime
processStartTime.description: The date/time at which this process started. The format is as follows: to local time in the form of a 26-character string as shown below. Time zone and daylight savings corrections are made before string generation. The fields are constant width: Fri Sep 13 00:00:00 1986\n

processStateStr.name: processStateStr
processStateStr.description: The process state in an operating-system independent format. A process-state matrix is included below. Note that not all operating systems may support a specific process-state. State Description -------- -------------------------------- starting Process under creation runnable Process is on run queue sleeping Process is waiting for event to complete sleep Uninterruptible sleep (usually IO) zombie Process terminated; parent not waiting stop Process stopped either by job control signal or because it is being traced active The process is running on a processor swapped Process is swapped out to secondary storage wait Process is waiting for memory; subclass of sleeping state other Misc state (forking, exiting, transition, etc.)

processStateInt.name: processStateInt
processStateInt.description: The process state, as above, represented by integer for easier polling and trending.

whoTable.name: whoTable
whoTable.description: This table represents users who are currently logged into the node which the agent resides.

whoEntry.name: whoEntry
whoEntry.description: An entry in the who table.

whoIndex.name: whoIndex
whoIndex.description: The instance of the whoEntry object.

whoName.name: whoName
whoName.description: The user name of a user logged into the node which the agent resides (e.g. root).

whoDevice.name: whoDevice
whoDevice.description: The device the user is using to log into the node which the agent resides (e.g. console or ttyp1).

whoPID.name: whoPID
whoPID.description: This object represents the process ID for the user's login shell. This object is not supported on SunOS 4.X systems; 0 is returned instead.

whoTime.name: whoTime
whoTime.description: The time, in SNMP TimeTicks, when the user first logged in.

whoWhere.name: whoWhere
whoWhere.description: The location the user logged in from if applicable. (e.g. :0.0 if local or host name if logged in from a remote system).

shellOutput.name: shellOutput
shellOutput.description: The name of a file that will receive all output from the execution of a UNIX command initiated by the agent. This file is restricted to the '/tmp' ('\temp' or '\tmp' for NT) directory for security and safety considerations. If the value object is set to anything other that that residing in '/tmp' or a relative pathname, an error will be returned.

shellCmd.name: shellCmd
shellCmd.description: The command and arguments to be executed by the agent. When this object is SET, (and a valid shellOutput object exists), the agent fork/execs the command with STDOUT and STDERR going to the value of shellOutput. On NT systems, the command is run synchronously so care should be taken not to block the subagent indefinitely.

shellExitStat.name: shellExitStat
shellExitStat.description: The exit code from the execution of a shell command. The value remains unchanged until another command is executed. Each execution of a shell command overwrites the previous value of this object. On some systems (HPUX-9), the exit status is not available if the shell command was invoked in the background in order to avoid defunct or zombie processes waiting on that shell command's exit value.

shellOutputContents.name: shellOutputContents
shellOutputContents.description: This object returns up to the first 512 characters of the last shell-command output stored in the file specified by shellOutput (remoteShell.1). No attempt at translating the character output is made by the agent.

runQLen.name: runQLen
runQLen.description: The length of the scheduler's run queue sampled over a fixed period of time. The sampling interval is system dependent. In SunOS, the kernel updates this parameter once every 5 seconds. The system's load average is computed from the value of runQLen; the load average is defined as the average runQLen value over some interval.

diskWaitNum.name: diskWaitNum
diskWaitNum.description: The number of jobs that are waiting on disk I/O sampled over a fixed period of time. The sampling interval is system dependent. In SunOS, the kernel updates this parameter once every 5 seconds. A large value may indicate an overloaded system although larger values may be observed on file server systems.

pageWaitNum.name: pageWaitNum
pageWaitNum.description: The number of jobs that are waiting on page I/O sampled over a fixed period of time. The sampling interval is system dependent. In SunOS, the kernel updates this parameter once every 5 seconds. A large value may indicate the system does not have enough memory for the current load.

swapActive.name: swapActive
swapActive.description: The number of jobs that are active yet swapped out of memory, sampled over a fixed period of time. The sampling interval is system dependent. In SunOS, the kernel updates this parameter once every 5 seconds. A high value for this object may indicate that system memory is not sufficient for the current load.

sleepActive.name: sleepActive
sleepActive.description: The number of jobs that are active yet sleeping in core, sampled over a fixed period of time. The sampling interval is system dependent. In SunOS, the kernel updates this parameter once every 5 seconds. A process is active yet sleeping in core when it is not running and not swapped out to secondary storage (swap).

memInUse.name: memInUse
memInUse.description: The total real KBytes of memory in use sampled over a fixed period of time. The sampling interval is system dependent. In SunOS, the kernel updates this parameter once every 5 seconds. Comparing memInUse to memory (in the Concord 'system' group) can help indicate if a system has sufficent memory for its current load.

activeMem.name: activeMem
activeMem.description: The total active real memory (KBytes) sampled over a fixed period of time. The sampling interval is system dependent. In SunOS, the kernel updates this parameter once every 5 seconds. Memory is active when it is actually being used by a process running in memory. This value should be less than or equal to memInUse. A high value may indicate a system with insufficient memory.

numProcs.name: numProcs
numProcs.description: The number of processes table slots currently allocated and in use. On older BSD-based systems, this metric is important since it places an uppder bound on the total number of processes that may run on the system at any one time.

numOpenFiles.name: numOpenFiles
numOpenFiles.description: The system-wide total number of open files.

swapInUse.name: swapInUse
swapInUse.description: The amount of swap space (KBytes) currently in use by the system. Swap space is used when memory is in short supply. Typically, entire processes are swapped out to secondary storage. Comparing this value to totalSwap (in Concord's kernelConfig group) can help indicate if additional swap space is needed.

numSwitches.name: numSwitches
numSwitches.description: The total number of context switches that have occurred since the kernel was last initialized. A context switch occurs each time a process gives up the CPU and another takes its place. This counter reflects the level of system activity; a high rate of context switching is indicative of the system load.

numTraps.name: numTraps
numTraps.description: The total number of traps switching a process from user to kernel mode that have occurred since the kernel was last initialized. Traps are hardware exceptions that occur and are usually caused by the currently running process. Example traps include those for incorrect arithmetic operations, segmentation violations or page faults. An excessive trap rate can indicate a faulty program, excessive system loading, or some other abnormality.

numSyscalls.name: numSyscalls
numSyscalls.description: The total number of system calls that have occurred since the kernel was last initialized. System calls occur when a process calls a function which must execute in kernel or privileged mode; it is a indicator of the system load and may be higher on servers or machines shared by many users.

numInterrupts.name: numInterrupts
numInterrupts.description: The total number of device interrupts that have occurred since the kernel was last initialized. The operating system is interrupted by devices and peripherals when they require the attention of the system. An excessive rate of interrupts can indicate a heavily loaded machine; servers and machines shared by many users will typically have a higher rate though.

numPageSwapIns.name: numPageSwapIns
numPageSwapIns.description: The total number of pages that have been swapped in since the kernel was last initialized. Page swapping occurs when a process is swapped to and from secondary storage. A high rate of page swap activity can indicate an overloaded system.

numPageSwapOuts.name: numPageSwapOuts
numPageSwapOuts.description: The total number of pages that have been swapped out since the kernel was last initialized. Page swapping occurs when a process is swapped to and from secondary storage. A high rate of page swap activity can indicate an overloaded system.

numSwapIns.name: numSwapIns
numSwapIns.description: The total number of processes that have been swapped in since the kernel was last initialized. Processes are swapped to and from secondary storage when memory is in short supply. A high rate may indicate an overloaded system.

numSwapOuts.name: numSwapOuts
numSwapOuts.description: The total number of processes that have been swapped out since the kernel was last initialized. Processes are swapped to and from secondary storage when memory is in short supply. A high rate may indicate an overloaded system.

numPageIns.name: numPageIns
numPageIns.description: The total number of pages that have been paged in since the kernel was last initialized. Page-in is an operation performed by the virtual memory system in which the contents of a page are read from secondary storage. A high rate of change may indicate an overloaded system.

numPageOuts.name: numPageOuts
numPageOuts.description: The total number of pages that have been paged out since the kernel was last initialized. Page-out is an operation performed by the virtual memory system in which the contents of a page are written to secondary storage. A high rate of change may indicate an overloaded system.

numPageReclaims.name: numPageReclaims
numPageReclaims.description: The total pages that have been reclaimed from the freelist since the kernel was last initialized. Memory pages are stored on a free-list when not in use. If a page has been acquired from the free-list, it has been reclaimed. A high rate of changed indicates an active system which is not generally considered to be overloaded.

numPageFaults.name: numPageFaults
numPageFaults.description: The total number of page faults that have occurred since the kernel was last initialized. A page fault occurs when a running process attempts to access a virtual memory page that is not currently in physical memory resulting in a hardware page fault. A high rage of page faults may indicate an overloaded system or one with insufficient memory.

loadAverage1Min.name: loadAverage1Min
loadAverage1Min.description: The load average over the last 1 minute. The load average represents the average number of jobs in the run queue over the specified time range. The value reported is the load average multiplied by 100. For example, if the value 50 represents a load average of 0.50

loadAverage5Min.name: loadAverage5Min
loadAverage5Min.description: The load average over the last 5 minutes. The load average represents the average number of jobs in the run queue over the specified time range. The value reported is the load average multiplied by 100. For example, if the value 50 represents a load average of 0.50

loadAverage15Min.name: loadAverage15Min
loadAverage15Min.description: The load average over the last 15 minutes. The load average represents the average number of jobs in the run queue over the specified time range. The value reported is the load average multiplied by 100. For example, if the value 50 represents a load average of 0.50

totalSwapSpace.name: totalSwapSpace
totalSwapSpace.description: Total system swap space in KBytes. This object is identical to the kernelConfig.totalSwap(12) object and is repeated here for the convenience of management stations which cannot simultaneously poll groups of objects in different branches of the MIB.

swapCapacity.name: swapCapacity
swapCapacity.description: The percentage of the system's total swap in use. The value of this object can be computed by dividing swapInUse(13) by totalSwapSpace(29) and multiplying by 100. It is included here for convenient polling, monitoring, and history sampling. This object is an aggregate value over all the swap partitions and areas.

memCapacity.name: memCapacity
memCapacity.description: The percentage of the system's active memory in use. The value of this object can be approximated by dividing activeMem(10) by memory(system.3) and converting to a percentage. Because virutal memory allows systems to operate with a higher memCapacity value, this value alone should not be used to judge how loaded a system is. Managers should also monitor swapCapacity.

memInUseCapacity.name: memInUseCapacity
memInUseCapacity.description: The percentage of the system's memory in use. The value of this object can be approximated by dividing memInUse(9) by memory(system.3) and converting to a percentage. Because virutal memory allows systems to operate with a higher memCapacity value, this value alone should not be used to judge how loaded a system is. Managers should also monitor swapCapacity.

pageScans.name: pageScans
pageScans.description: Total number of pages examined by pageout daemon. Excessive rates of scans (change in this counter) can indicate a machine with insufficient memory.

numZombieProcs.name: numZombieProcs
numZombieProcs.description: Current number of zombie processes found on the system. This MIB object is found by adding up all processes with a processStateStr of zombie. The lower the number the better. Supported in SystemEDGE 4.1 and higher.

errorTable.name: errorTable
errorTable.description: This table contains errors reported to the system console. On System V.4 platforms, it also contains errors passed up via the system error device. Note, errors in this table are also sent out as TRAPS. V.4 derived systems support a flexible, consistent interface for hardware and system errors. This table represents error feedback from this interface. It is not supported on SunOS 4.X systems.

errorEntry.name: errorEntry
errorEntry.description: An entry in the error table.

seqNum.name: seqNum
seqNum.description: The unique sequence number of the error entry. The value of this object also represents the instance of the errorEntry object.

mid.name: mid
mid.description: The software module identifier reporting the error.

sid.name: sid
sid.description: The secondary identifier of the module reporting the error.

time.name: time
time.description: The time at which the error was reported and the error entry created.

tag.name: tag
tag.description: A unique number which identifies the type of error that occurred.

level.name: level
level.description: The level of software reporting the error.

module.name: module
module.description: The module name that reported the error.

subSysmsg.name: subSysmsg
subSysmsg.description: The sub-system message of the error entry.

errDelete.name: errDelete
errDelete.description: Setting this object to the value 1 causes the agent to delete this entry from the error table. Writing any other value causes the agent to take no action.

msgqueTable.name: msgqueTable
msgqueTable.description: This table contains an entry for each system SysV message queue currently in use.

msgqueEntry.name: msgqueEntry
msgqueEntry.description: An entry in the message queue table.

queID.name: queID
queID.description: The unique queue ID. The value of this object also represents the instance for the queEntry object.

queKey.name: queKey
queKey.description: The message queue key. Each message queue has a key value chosen by the creating user. Its value is only significant to the creating process.

queMode.name: queMode
queMode.description: The message queue permissions mode. The mode defines access permissions for the message queue as well as status information. See the man page ipcs(1) for more information.

queOwner.name: queOwner
queOwner.description: The login name (e.g. root) of the owner of the message queue.

queGroup.name: queGroup
queGroup.description: The group name (e.g. wheel) of the owner of the message queue.

queNBytes.name: queNBytes
queNBytes.description: The number of bytes currently in the message queue.

queNMesg.name: queNMesg
queNMesg.description: The number of messages currently in the message queue.

queDel.name: queDel
queDel.description: Setting this object to the value 1 causes this agent to remove the message queue from its table. The message queue identifier is removed from the system-wide table and the kernel message queue and associated data structure are destroyed.

shmemTable.name: shmemTable
shmemTable.description: This table contains an entry for each system SysV shared memory segment currently in use.

shmemEntry.name: shmemEntry
shmemEntry.description: An entry in the shared memory table.

shmemID.name: shmemID
shmemID.description: The unique shared memory segment ID. The value of this object also represents the instance of the shmemEntry object.

shmemKey.name: shmemKey
shmemKey.description: The shared memory segment key. Each shared memory segment is assigned a key value by the creating user. Its value is only significant to the creating process.

shmemMode.name: shmemMode
shmemMode.description: The shared memory segment permissions mode. The mode defines access permissions for the message queue as well as status information. See the man page ipcs(1) for more information.

shmemOwner.name: shmemOwner
shmemOwner.description: The user login name (e.g. root) of the owner of the shared memory segment.

shmemGroup.name: shmemGroup
shmemGroup.description: The group name (e.g. wheel) of the owner of the shared memory segment.

shmemSegSz.name: shmemSegSz
shmemSegSz.description: The size in bytes of the shared memory segment

shmemNLcks.name: shmemNLcks
shmemNLcks.description: The number of times the shared memory segment has been locked.

shmemDel.name: shmemDel
shmemDel.description: Setting this object to the value of 1 causes the agent to remove this entry from the table. The shared memory identifier is removed from the system-wide table and the kernel shared memory segment and associated data structure are destroyed.

semTable.name: semTable
semTable.description: This table contains an entry for each system SysV semaphore currently in use.

semEntry.name: semEntry
semEntry.description: An entry in the semaphore table.

semID.name: semID
semID.description: The unique semaphore ID. The value of this object represents the instance for the semEntry object.

semKey.name: semKey
semKey.description: The semaphore's key. Each semaphore is assigned a key value by the creating user. Its value is only significant to the creating process.

semMode.name: semMode
semMode.description: The semaphore permissions mode. The mode defines access permissions for the message queue as well as status information. See the man page ipcs(1) for more information.

semOwner.name: semOwner
semOwner.description: The user login name (e.g. root) of the owner of the semaphore.

semGroup.name: semGroup
semGroup.description: The group name (e.g. wheel) of the owner of the semaphore.

semNsems.name: semNsems
semNsems.description: The number of individual semaphores within this semaphore group.

semDel.name: semDel
semDel.description: Setting the value of 1, causes the agent to remove this entry from its semaphore table. The semaphore identifier is removed from the system-wide table and the kernel semaphore group and associated data structures are destroyed.

numMbufs.name: numMbufs
numMbufs.description: The total number of mbufs contained in the mbuf pool. The BSD networking subsystem utilizes a buffer abstraction called 'mbufs'. This object indicates the number of mbuf buffers pre-allocated by the operating system. If the BSD networking subsystem is not supported, than 0 is returned.

numClusters.name: numClusters
numClusters.description: The total number of logical pages or clusters obtained from the page pool. Memory pages (or clusters) can also be attached to mbufs if needed. The size of this pool is returned in this object. If the BSD subsystem is not supported, than 0 is returned.

freeClusters.name: freeClusters
freeClusters.description: The number of free clusters or memory pages in the mbuf cluster pool. Monitoring the number of free clusters can help determine if the BSD protocol subsystem is properly configured. On SunOS 4.X systems, TCP/IP is coded in the BSD subsystem. Monitoring this variable can help determine if TCP/IP performance problems are due to insufficient buffer resources.

numDrops.name: numDrops
numDrops.description: The number of times requests for mbufs were denied. An excessive rate of mbuf allocation failures may indicate an overloaded system or one with insufficient memory resources.

numWaits.name: numWaits
numWaits.description: The number of times requests for mbufs were delayed. An excessive rate of mbuf allocation 'waits' may indicate an overloaded system or one with insufficient memory resources.

numDrains.name: numDrains
numDrains.description: The total number of calls to protocol drain routines. When the protocol subsystem is running low on buffers, it can call each protocol's 'drain' function forcing that protocol to free buffers. This object reveals how many times this even has occurred. An excessive rate of calls to 'drain' may indicate an overloaded or misconfigured system.

mbufAllocTable.name: mbufAllocTable
mbufAllocTable.description: This table contains an entry for each mbuf type that has been allocated. In the BSD networking subsystem, when an mbuf is allocated, the mbuf's intended use is categorized. This table represents the categories and the number of mbuf's allocated to each type.

mbufAllocEntry.name: mbufAllocEntry
mbufAllocEntry.description: An entry in the mbuf Allocation table.

mbufType.name: mbufType
mbufType.description: The type of mbuf. Mbuf types generally range from from 0 to 255; many mbuf types (numbers > 30) are undefined and generally not used. Their use and description are a local matter and may vary from system to system.

mbufDesc.name: mbufDesc
mbufDesc.description: A textual description of the mbuf type. Example mbuf descriptions include 'Packet header', 'Socket structure', etc. Undefined or unknown mbuf type descriptions return 'Unknown mbuf type' as their description.

mbufAlloc.name: mbufAlloc
mbufAlloc.description: The number of mbufs allocated and declared of to be of this type.

strbufAllocTable.name: strbufAllocTable
strbufAllocTable.description: This table contains an entry for each Streams buffer bucket sizes.

strbufAllocEntry.name: strbufAllocEntry
strbufAllocEntry.description: An entry in the Streams buffer allocation table.

strbufAllocIndex.name: strbufAllocIndex
strbufAllocIndex.description: The table index of this entry.

strbufAllocSize.name: strbufAllocSize
strbufAllocSize.description: The size of this bucket in bytes. The size is less than or equal to this value yet greater than the previous entry's bucket size. For example, if the bucket size os 1024 bytes, all Streams buffer requests of less than or equal to 1024 bytes will return a buffer of size 1024.

strbufAllocCurrent.name: strbufAllocCurrent
strbufAllocCurrent.description: The number of Streams buffers of this currently allocated. Comparing the value of this object to strbufAllocMax can help one determine if the system is properly configured.

strbufAllocMaxs.name: strbufAllocMaxs
strbufAllocMaxs.description: The maximum number of Streams buffers of this size ever allocated at any one time. This value serves as a high-water mark for buffer allocations of this size.

strbufAllocTotals.name: strbufAllocTotals
strbufAllocTotals.description: The total number of allocations of Streams buffers of this bucket size. A high allocation rate can help one diagnose an overloaded system.

strbufAllocFails.name: strbufAllocFails
strbufAllocFails.description: The total number of allocation failures for Streams buffers of this bucket size. A high rate of failure can indicate an overloaded system or one that is not properly configured.

numBreadRequests.name: numBreadRequests
numBreadRequests.description: The total number of calls to the kernel's bread() function. This function is the primary read interface to the kernel's buffer pool used for file system I/O. On NT systems, this value is an aggregate of several read variables in the ntCachePerf group.

numBreadHits.name: numBreadHits
numBreadHits.description: The number of kernel buffer cache 'hits'. The kernel caches previously used I/O buffers in an attempt to avoid excessive reading and writing to disk. A cache 'hit' indicates that this strategy has paid off because a process has requested a buffer that was in the buffer cache thereby avoiding a more expensive disk read. A high rate of cache hits indicates a relatively smooth running system. On NT systems, this value is an aggregate of several hit variables in the ntCachePerf group.

numBufSleeps.name: numBufSleeps
numBufSleeps.description: The total number of times the kernel had to 'sleep' for a buffer. The kernel 'sleeps' for a buffer when it fails to find it in the cache and must access the disk for it. Excessive buffer 'sleeps' indicates that the caching algorithm is not able to effectively predict and cache disk I/O patterns. Adding more memory for buffering may improve the cache hit ratio.

numAgeAllocs.name: numAgeAllocs
numAgeAllocs.description: The total number of times an aged buffer was allocated. The buffer pool is stored in one of several lists. One such list, the AGE list, holds buffers buffers that have a lower probability of being used. New buffer requests are filled from this list first. This variable contains the number of times a buffer request was satisfied by a buffer on the AGE list.

numLRUAllocs.name: numLRUAllocs
numLRUAllocs.description: The total number times an LRU buffer was allocated. The Least-recently-used list is another list on which buffers are stored. They are allocated in a 'least-recently-used' manner. This variable indicates the number of times a buffer was allocated from the LRU list.

minNumBufHdrs.name: minNumBufHdrs
minNumBufHdrs.description: The minimum number of buffer headers to allocated. These headers are used at the head of each buffer hash list. This value represents an upper bound on the number of separate hash lists the buffer cache may use.

numAllocBuf.name: numAllocBuf
numAllocBuf.description: Number of buffers that are currently allocated. Monitoring this variable, and others in the ioBufferCache group, can help indicate if the system is properly configured or has sufficient memory for buffering.

ioBufferHitRate.name: ioBufferHitRate
ioBufferHitRate.description: Percentage of buffer cache lookups that result in a 'hit'. This value is derived from numBreadHits / numBreadRequests.

dnlcHits.name: dnlcHits
dnlcHits.description: Total number of DNLC cache hits.

dnlcMisses.name: dnlcMisses
dnlcMisses.description: Total number of DNLC cache misses.

dnlcEnters.name: dnlcEnters
dnlcEnters.description: Total number of DNLC enters done.

dnlcDblEnters.name: dnlcDblEnters
dnlcDblEnters.description: Total number enters tried when already cached.

dnlcLongEnters.name: dnlcLongEnters
dnlcLongEnters.description: Total number of long names tried to enter.

dnlcLongLooks.name: dnlcLongLooks
dnlcLongLooks.description: Total number of long name lookup attempts.

dnlcLruEmpty.name: dnlcLruEmpty
dnlcLruEmpty.description: Total number of least-recently used list empty.

dnlcPurges.name: dnlcPurges
dnlcPurges.description: Total number of purges to the DNLC cache.

dnlcHitRate.name: dnlcHitRate
dnlcHitRate.description: Percentage of DNLC cache lookups that result in a 'hit'. Hit rates less than 90% are considered poor and may require kernel tuning. This value is derived from dnlcHits / dnlcHits + dnlcMisses.

dnlcCacheSize.name: dnlcCacheSize
dnlcCacheSize.description: The maximum number of possible entries in the DNLC cache. If there is no set upper bound, 0 is returned.

ntSystemVersion.name: ntSystemVersion
ntSystemVersion.description: The kernel/system version including the release, build, and service-pack numbers.

ntServicePackNumber.name: ntServicePackNumber
ntServicePackNumber.description: The system service-pack number. If no service-packs have been applied, then 0 is returned.

ntWorkstationOrServer.name: ntWorkstationOrServer
ntWorkstationOrServer.description: The type of NT system -- NT Server or NT Workstation

ntfsDisable8dot3NameCreation.name: ntfsDisable8dot3NameCreation
ntfsDisable8dot3NameCreation.description: This object reflects whether the underlying NT system has enabled or disabled the creation of short names to correspond with long filenames. For example, if enabled, then NT will create a short filename to correspond to a file created with a long filename. This feature is often enabled if backward compatibility with DOS based applications is desired.

ntWin31FileSystem.name: ntWin31FileSystem
ntWin31FileSystem.description: This object reflects whether the FAT will allow creation, enumeration, opening, or querying of long file names, and whether extended time stamp information is stored and reported. Setting to true(1) reverts the system back to Win3x semantics.

ntCriticalSectTimeout.name: ntCriticalSectTimeout
ntCriticalSectTimeout.description: The deadlock time-out for critical sections.

ntGlobalFlag.name: ntGlobalFlag
ntGlobalFlag.description: NT system global hexadecimal flag that controls various internal operations.

ntIoPageLockLimit.name: ntIoPageLockLimit
ntIoPageLockLimit.description: Specifies the limit of the number of bytes that can be locked for I/O operations. When 0, the default (512k) is used.

ntLargeSystemCache.name: ntLargeSystemCache
ntLargeSystemCache.description: A nonzero value indicates that the system favors the system-cache working set rather than the processes working set.

ntPagedPoolSize.name: ntPagedPoolSize
ntPagedPoolSize.description: Size of paged pool in bytes. When 0, system uses default size (32 MB).

ntNonPagedPoolSize.name: ntNonPagedPoolSize
ntNonPagedPoolSize.description: Size of nonpaged pool in bytes. When 0, system uses default size (based on physical memory).

ntPagingFiles.name: ntPagingFiles
ntPagingFiles.description: List of paging files and their sizes used by the system for paging. For each paging file the description includes the file pathname, current size in MB and maximum size in MB.

ntSystemPages.name: ntSystemPages
ntSystemPages.description: This object defines the number of system page table entries reserved for I/O buffers and other information.

ntOptionalSubsystem.name: ntOptionalSubsystem
ntOptionalSubsystem.description: This object lists those subsystems that are only loaded when the user starts a depending application.

ntCmdlineOptions.name: ntCmdlineOptions
ntCmdlineOptions.description: This object lists the command-line that runs when an MS-DOS application is launched under NT.

ntLPTTimeout.name: ntLPTTimeout
ntLPTTimeout.description: This object defines how many seconds after the LPT port has been used that Windows NT waits before grabbing the port, closing it, and flushing the output. This value is only needed for MS-DOS based applications that use BIOS and do not close the port.

ntDosMemSize.name: ntDosMemSize
ntDosMemSize.description: Size in MBytes of memory to be given to each individual MS-DOS virtual DOS machine (VDM).

ntWowCmdline.name: ntWowCmdline
ntWowCmdline.description: This object defines the command line that runs when a 16-bit Windows-based application is started. The switches instruct NT to start either an MS-DOS VDM or a WOW VDM.

ntWowSize.name: ntWowSize
ntWowSize.description: For RISC based computers, this object defines the amount of memory provided in a VDM when a WOW session is started. Value is in MBytes.

ntUserFullScreen.name: ntUserFullScreen
ntUserFullScreen.description: This object indicates whether full-screen or windowed mode is used for the console by default. Valid on x86 machines only.

ntHistoryBufferSize.name: ntHistoryBufferSize
ntHistoryBufferSize.description: This object indicates the number of commands stored in the history buffer by default.

ntNumberHistoryBuffers.name: ntNumberHistoryBuffers
ntNumberHistoryBuffers.description: This object indicates the number of history buffers associated with the console by default.

ntQuickEdit.name: ntQuickEdit
ntQuickEdit.description: This object indicates if Quick-Edit mode is enabled by default.

ntScreenBufferSize.name: ntScreenBufferSize
ntScreenBufferSize.description: Width and height of the default console screen buffer.

ntWindowSize.name: ntWindowSize
ntWindowSize.description: Default width and height of the console window.

ntWindowsAppInitDLLs.name: ntWindowsAppInitDLLs
ntWindowsAppInitDLLs.description: Lists the DLLs that will be attached to all Windows-based applications.

ntWindowsDeviceNotSelectedTimeout.name: ntWindowsDeviceNotSelectedTimeout
ntWindowsDeviceNotSelectedTimeout.description: Indicates how much time the system waits for a devices to be switched on.

ntWindowsSpooler.name: ntWindowsSpooler
ntWindowsSpooler.description: Indicates whether printer output is be sent through Print Manager.

ntWindowsSwapDisk.name: ntWindowsSwapDisk
ntWindowsSwapDisk.description: Indicates the name of disk drive and directory to which Windows for MS-DOS in standard-mode swaps non-Windows-based applications.

ntWindowsXmitRetryTimeout.name: ntWindowsXmitRetryTimeout
ntWindowsXmitRetryTimeout.description: Transmission retry timeout in seconds used by Print Manager.

ntSystemRoot.name: ntSystemRoot
ntSystemRoot.description: Drive and directory where the NT system resides.

ntCrashDumpEnabled.name: ntCrashDumpEnabled
ntCrashDumpEnabled.description: This object indicates whether debugging information is to be written to a log file in the event of a system crash.

ntLogEvent.name: ntLogEvent
ntLogEvent.description: This object indicates whether NTAS logging is enabled or disabled. If disabled, NT workstation logging is used.

ntOverwrite.name: ntOverwrite
ntOverwrite.description: Indicates whether an existing log file is to be overwritten by the new one. Enabled for NTAS, disabled for NT workstation.

ntSendAlert.name: ntSendAlert
ntSendAlert.description: Indicates whether an administrative alert is sent; enabled for NTAS, disabled for NT workstation.

ntIsClustered.name: ntIsClustered
ntIsClustered.description: Indicates whether this system is installed and/or running in a windows cluster

ntClusterName.name: ntClusterName
ntClusterName.description: The cluster name that this system is a member of. If the system is not a member of any cluster, then a zero-length string is returned. The cluster name can then be used with DNS or NetBIOS to determine the virtual address of the logical cluster.

ntClusterMembers.name: ntClusterMembers
ntClusterMembers.description: A comma-separated list of nodes that are members of the cluster in which this system is a member. Using this information, management software can determine the members of a logical cluster and act accordingly to deal with the logical cluster and the individual nodes.

ntClusterIsActive.name: ntClusterIsActive
ntClusterIsActive.description: Indicates whether this system is the primary or active node in the NT cluster. It does not necessarily say if the cluster service(s) are active and up and running per se.

ntClusterActiveNode.name: ntClusterActiveNode
ntClusterActiveNode.description: Indicates which of cluster members is active or primary node. Active node owns the Cluster Name resource object.

ntThreadEntry.name: ntThreadEntry
ntThreadEntry.description: An entry in the NT system thread table.

ntThreadPID.name: ntThreadPID
ntThreadPID.description: The unique process ID with which this thread is contained and executing within.

ntThreadNumber.name: ntThreadNumber
ntThreadNumber.description: The thread number within a given process. Thread numbers are not unique across all threads in the system.

ntThreadPrivTime.name: ntThreadPrivTime
ntThreadPrivTime.description: The total elapsed time (in centiseconds) that this thread has executed in Privileged Mode.

ntThreadProcTime.name: ntThreadProcTime
ntThreadProcTime.description: The total elapsed time (in centiseconds) that this thread has used the processor to execute instructions.

ntThreadUserTime.name: ntThreadUserTime
ntThreadUserTime.description: Total elapsed time (in centiseconds) that this thread has executed in User Mode.

ntThreadElapsedTime.name: ntThreadElapsedTime
ntThreadElapsedTime.description: The total elapsed time (in seconds) this thread has been running.

ntThreadPriorityBase.name: ntThreadPriorityBase
ntThreadPriorityBase.description: The current base priority of this thread. The system may alter the thread's dynamic priority above, below the base priority.

ntThreadPriority.name: ntThreadPriority
ntThreadPriority.description: The current dynamic priority of this thread.

ntThreadWaitReason.name: ntThreadWaitReason
ntThreadWaitReason.description: Reason thread is waiting; valid only if ntThreadState is currently wait(5), otherwise undefined.

ntThreadStartAddr.name: ntThreadStartAddr
ntThreadStartAddr.description: The starting virtual address of this thread.

ntThreadState.name: ntThreadState
ntThreadState.description: The current state of this thread.

ntThreadID.name: ntThreadID
ntThreadID.description: The system-wide unique identifier associated with this thread.

ntRegistryCurrentSize.name: ntRegistryCurrentSize
ntRegistryCurrentSize.description: The current size of the registry in MBytes.

ntRegistrySizeLimit.name: ntRegistrySizeLimit
ntRegistrySizeLimit.description: The size limit of the registry in MBytes.

ntServiceEntry.name: ntServiceEntry
ntServiceEntry.description: An entry in the NT system service table.

ntServiceIndex.name: ntServiceIndex
ntServiceIndex.description: The index of this system service.

ntServiceStartType.name: ntServiceStartType
ntServiceStartType.description: The manner in which the service is started; automatic(1) implies that the system starts the service at boot time while manual(2) implies that the service must be started by hand by an administrator. Disabled(3) indicates that the service cannot be started.

ntServiceParameters.name: ntServiceParameters
ntServiceParameters.description: The parameters passed to this service when it is invoked.

ntServiceState.name: ntServiceState
ntServiceState.description: The current state of the system service.

ntServiceObjectName.name: ntServiceObjectName
ntServiceObjectName.description: The object name for this service. This indicates the user name the service is currently running as.

ntTotalPrivTime.name: ntTotalPrivTime
ntTotalPrivTime.description: Running counter of centiseconds spent by the system processor(s) in Privileged mode.

ntTotalProcessorTime.name: ntTotalProcessorTime
ntTotalProcessorTime.description: Running counter of centiseconds spent by the system processor(s) running Idle threads. Note that this is actually the inverse of the total processor time.

ntTotalUserTime.name: ntTotalUserTime
ntTotalUserTime.description: Running counter of centiseconds spent by the system processor(s) running User mode.

ntAlignFixups.name: ntAlignFixups
ntAlignFixups.description: The number of alignment faults fixed by the system.

ntContextSwitches.name: ntContextSwitches
ntContextSwitches.description: The total number of context switches that have occurred since the kernel was last initialized. A context switch occurs each time a thread gives up the CPU and another takes its place. This counter reflects the level of system activity; a high rate of context switching is indicative of the system load. This counter is equivalent (for NT systems) to the UNIX counter numSwitches(kernelperf.14)

ntExceptionDispatches.name: ntExceptionDispatches
ntExceptionDispatches.description: The total number of exceptions dispacted by the system since it was initialized.

ntFileCtrlKBytes.name: ntFileCtrlKBytes
ntFileCtrlKBytes.description: An aggregate of KBytes transferred for all file system operations that are neither reads or writes (e.g. file system control requests or device control requests).

ntFileCtrlOps.name: ntFileCtrlOps
ntFileCtrlOps.description: Aggregate counter of all file system operations that are neither reads nor writes.

ntFileDataOps.name: ntFileDataOps
ntFileDataOps.description: Total number of read and write operations to file system devices issued by the system since system initialization.

ntReadKBytes.name: ntReadKBytes
ntReadKBytes.description: Aggregate number of KBytes transferred for all the file system read operations on this system since system initialization.

ntReadOps.name: ntReadOps
ntReadOps.description: Aggregate of all the file system read operations on this system since system initialization.

ntWriteKBytes.name: ntWriteKBytes
ntWriteKBytes.description: Aggregate number of KBytes transferred for all the file system write operations on this system since system initialization.

ntWriteOps.name: ntWriteOps
ntWriteOps.description: Aggregate number of all the file system write operations on this system since system initialization.

ntFloatEmuls.name: ntFloatEmuls
ntFloatEmuls.description: Number of floating emulations performed by the system.

ntRunQLen.name: ntRunQLen
ntRunQLen.description: Instantaneous processor queue length in threads and is equivalent to runQLen(kernelperf.4)

ntSystemCalls.name: ntSystemCalls
ntSystemCalls.description: The number of calls to system service routines. This object is equivalent to numSyscalls(kernelperf.16)

ntInterrupts.name: ntInterrupts
ntInterrupts.description: The number of hardware interrupts that have occurred. This object is equivalent to numInterrupts(kernelperf.17)

ntAsyncCopyReads.name: ntAsyncCopyReads
ntAsyncCopyReads.description: Number of async reads from Cache pages involving a memory copy of the data from the Cache to the application's buffer.

ntAsyncDataMaps.name: ntAsyncDataMaps
ntAsyncDataMaps.description: Number of async data maps of file pages into the Cache.

ntAsyncFastReads.name: ntAsyncFastReads
ntAsyncFastReads.description: Number of direct-to-Cache async read operations.

ntAsyncMDLReads.name: ntAsyncMDLReads
ntAsyncMDLReads.description: Number of async memory descriptor list (MDL) reads from the Cache. The MDL contains the physical address of each page in the transfer thus permitting DMA of the pages.

ntAsyncPinReads.name: ntAsyncPinReads
ntAsyncPinReads.description: Number of async reads from the Cache in preparation to writing the data back to disk. Pages read in this fashion are pinned in memory at the completion of the read.

ntCopyReadHits.name: ntCopyReadHits
ntCopyReadHits.description: Number of Cache Copy Read requests that hit the cache and did not require a disk read.

ntCopyReads.name: ntCopyReads
ntCopyReads.description: The number of reads from Cache pages that involved a memory copy of data from the Cache to the application's buffer.

ntDataFlushPages.name: ntDataFlushPages
ntDataFlushPages.description: Number of pages of the Cache flushed to disk as a result of a flush request or to satisfy a write-through request.

ntDataFlushes.name: ntDataFlushes
ntDataFlushes.description: Number of Cache data flush operations.

ntDataMapHits.name: ntDataMapHits
ntDataMapHits.description: Numberof data maps in the Cache that could be resolved without retrieval from disk.

ntDataMapPins.name: ntDataMapPins
ntDataMapPins.description: Number of data maps in the Cache that resulted in pinning a page in main memory.

ntDataMaps.name: ntDataMaps
ntDataMaps.description: Number of times a file system such as NTFS or HPFS has mapped a page of a file into the Cache to read the page.

ntFastReadNotPossible.name: ntFastReadNotPossible
ntFastReadNotPossible.description: Number of times an API function call to bypass the file system to get at Cache data could not be honored without invoking the file system after all.

ntFastReadResourceMisses.name: ntFastReadResourceMisses
ntFastReadResourceMisses.description: Number of Cache misses necessitated by the lack of available resources to satisfy the request.

ntFastReads.name: ntFastReads
ntFastReads.description: Number of reads from Cache pages that bypass installed file systems and read from the Cache directly.

ntLazyWriteFlushes.name: ntLazyWriteFlushes
ntLazyWriteFlushes.description: The number of times the Cache's Lazy Write thread has written to disk.

ntLazyWritePages.name: ntLazyWritePages
ntLazyWritePages.description: Number of pages the Cache's Lazy Write thread has written to disk. Lazy Writing is the process of updating the disk after the page has been changed in memory so the application making the change to the file does not have to wait for the disk write to complete before proceeding.

ntMDLReadHits.name: ntMDLReadHits
ntMDLReadHits.description: Number of Cache Memory Descriptor List (MDL) read requests that hit the Cache.

ntPinReadHits.name: ntPinReadHits
ntPinReadHits.description: Number Cache Pin Read requests that hit the Cache.

ntPinReads.name: ntPinReads
ntPinReads.description: Number of pages read from the Cache that have been pinned in memory.

ntSyncCopyReads.name: ntSyncCopyReads
ntSyncCopyReads.description: Number of reads from Cache pages that wait for the copy operation to complete before proceeding.

ntSyncDataMaps.name: ntSyncDataMaps
ntSyncDataMaps.description: Number of times that a file system such as NTFS or HPFS maps a page of a file into the Cache to read the page.

ntSyncFastReads.name: ntSyncFastReads
ntSyncFastReads.description: Number of sync reads from Cache pages that bypass the installed file system and retrieve the data directly from the Cache.

ntSyncMDLReads.name: ntSyncMDLReads
ntSyncMDLReads.description: Number of reads from Cache pages that use a Memory Descriptor List (MDL) to access the pages.

ntSyncPinReads.name: ntSyncPinReads
ntSyncPinReads.description: Number of page reads that have resulted in the page being pinned in memory.

ntAvailKBytes.name: ntAvailKBytes
ntAvailKBytes.description: Number of KBytes of virtual memory currently on the Zeroed, Free, and Standby lists. Zeroed and free memory is ready for use. Standby memory is memory removed from a process's working set but still available.

ntCacheKBytes.name: ntCacheKBytes
ntCacheKBytes.description: Number of KBytes currently in use by the system Cache.

ntCacheKBytesPeak.name: ntCacheKBytesPeak
ntCacheKBytesPeak.description: Maximum number of KBytes used by the system Cache.

ntCacheFaults.name: ntCacheFaults
ntCacheFaults.description: Number of Cache faults whereby memory had to be located elsewhere.

ntCommitLimit.name: ntCommitLimit
ntCommitLimit.description: Size in KBytes of virtual memory that can be committed without having to expand the paging file(s).

ntCommittedKBytes.name: ntCommittedKBytes
ntCommittedKBytes.description: Number of KBytes of virtual memory that have been committed.

ntDemandZeroFaults.name: ntDemandZeroFaults
ntDemandZeroFaults.description: Number of page faults for pages that must be filled with zeros before fault is satisifed.

ntFreeSysPageTableEntries.name: ntFreeSysPageTableEntries
ntFreeSysPageTableEntries.description: Number of Page Table entries not currently in use by the system.

ntPageFaults.name: ntPageFaults
ntPageFaults.description: Number of page faults in the processor and is equivalent to numPageFaults(kernelperf.25)

ntPageReads.name: ntPageReads
ntPageReads.description: Number of times the disk was read to retrieve pages of virtual memory.

ntPageWrites.name: ntPageWrites
ntPageWrites.description: Number of times pages have been written to disk.

ntPagesInput.name: ntPagesInput
ntPagesInput.description: Number of pages read from disk to resolve memory references and is equivalent to numPageIns (kernelperf.22)

ntPagesOutput.name: ntPagesOutput
ntPagesOutput.description: Number of pages written to disk because the pages were modified and is equivalent to numPageOuts (kernelperf.23).

ntPages.name: ntPages
ntPages.description: Number of pages read or written from/to disk and is a sum of PagesInput(12) and PagesOutput(13).

ntPoolNonPagedAllocs.name: ntPoolNonPagedAllocs
ntPoolNonPagedAllocs.description: Number of calls to allocate space in the system Nonpaged pool.

ntPoolNonPagedKBytes.name: ntPoolNonPagedKBytes
ntPoolNonPagedKBytes.description: Number of KBytes in the Nonpaged pool which is a system memory area where space is acquired by operating systems facilities as they accomplish their tasks. These pages cannot be paged out to disk.

ntPoolPagedAllocs.name: ntPoolPagedAllocs
ntPoolPagedAllocs.description: Number of calls to allocate space in the system Paged Pool. Paged Pool is a system memory area where space is acquired by operating systems facilities as they accomplish their tasks. Paged Pool bytes may be paged out to disk when not accessed by the system for sustained periods of time.

ntPoolPagedKBytes.name: ntPoolPagedKBytes
ntPoolPagedKBytes.description: Number of KBytes in the Paged Pool.

ntPagedResidentKBytes.name: ntPagedResidentKBytes
ntPagedResidentKBytes.description: Size of paged Pool resident in core memory in KBytes.

ntSysCacheResidentKBytes.name: ntSysCacheResidentKBytes
ntSysCacheResidentKBytes.description: Number of KBytes currently resident in the global disk cache.

ntSysCodeResidentKBytes.name: ntSysCodeResidentKBytes
ntSysCodeResidentKBytes.description: Number of KBytes of System Code Total Bytes currently resident in core memory. This is the code working set of the pagable executive.

ntSysCodeTotalKBytes.name: ntSysCodeTotalKBytes
ntSysCodeTotalKBytes.description: Total number of KBytes of pageable pages in ntoskrnl.exe, hal.dll, and the boot drivers and file systems loaded by ntldr/osloader.

ntSysDriverResidentKBytes.name: ntSysDriverResidentKBytes
ntSysDriverResidentKBytes.description: Number of KBytes of System Driver Total KBytes currently resident in core memory. The number is the code working set of the pagable drivers.

ntSysDriverTotalKBytes.name: ntSysDriverTotalKBytes
ntSysDriverTotalKBytes.description: Number of KBytes of pageable pages in all other loaded device drivers.

ntTransitionFaults.name: ntTransitionFaults
ntTransitionFaults.description: Number of page faults resolved by recovering pages that were in transition to disk at time of page fault.

ntWriteCopies.name: ntWriteCopies
ntWriteCopies.description: Number of page faults that have been satisfied by making a copy of a page when an attempt to write the page was made while it was shared.

ntPageFileUsage.name: ntPageFileUsage
ntPageFileUsage.description: The percentage of the page file(s) used.

ntPageFilePeakUsage.name: ntPageFilePeakUsage
ntPageFilePeakUsage.description: The peak usage of the page file(s).

ntEventApplicationCount.name: ntEventApplicationCount
ntEventApplicationCount.description: The number of events in the Application event log.

ntEventSecurityCount.name: ntEventSecurityCount
ntEventSecurityCount.description: The number of events in the Security event log.

ntEventSystemCount.name: ntEventSystemCount
ntEventSystemCount.description: The number of events in the System event log.

ntEventMonTable.name: ntEventMonTable
ntEventMonTable.description: Table containing NT Event Log monitor entries; each entry specifies an Event Log and regular expression. The agent periodically stats the event logs to see if they have been updated. If updated, the agent scans the new entries for the regular expressions. When an entry is found that matches the regular expressions, a trap PDU is sent to appropriate managers.

ntEventMonIndex.name: ntEventMonIndex
ntEventMonIndex.description: An index that uniquely identifies an entry in the ntEventMonTable.

ntEventMonLog.name: ntEventMonLog
ntEventMonLog.description: The number identifying the NT event log to scan for pattern matches. Possible values are Application(1), Security(2), and System(3). On Win2k and higher, dnsServer(4), dirService(5), and fileRepService(6) are also possibly valid. Not all win2k+ systems have these event logs.

ntEventMonTime.name: ntEventMonTime
ntEventMonTime.description: The time (based on sysUpTime) at which the event occurred.

ntEventMonTraps.name: ntEventMonTraps
ntEventMonTraps.description: The number of traps sent by the agent on behalf of this entry. One trap PDU message is sent for each match the agent detects in the corresponding event log. This MIB object used to be called ntEventMonMatches but has been renamed to better reflect its true semantics.

ntEventMonTypeLastMatch.name: ntEventMonTypeLastMatch
ntEventMonTypeLastMatch.description: The number identifying the event type of the last event that matched the search criteria. Types 1 through 5 are defined by Windows NT. Type noMatch(6) indicates that there has not yet been a matching event for this monitoring entry.

ntEventMonTypeFilter.name: ntEventMonTypeFilter
ntEventMonTypeFilter.description: The number identifying the event type to match. Types 1 through 5 are defined by Windows NT. Type all(6) indicates that all event types will match.

ntEventMonSrcLastMatch.name: ntEventMonSrcLastMatch
ntEventMonSrcLastMatch.description: The source name of the last event log entry that matched this monitor entry. Each time a match occurs, this variable is updated.

ntEventMonSrcFilter.name: ntEventMonSrcFilter
ntEventMonSrcFilter.description: The display string representation of the regular expression to match the source name in the event log. Valid regular expressions are those as defined in ed(1).

ntEventMonDescLastMatch.name: ntEventMonDescLastMatch
ntEventMonDescLastMatch.description: The text description message from the last event log entry that matched this monitor entry. Each time a match occurs, this variable is updated.

ntEventMonDescFilter.name: ntEventMonDescFilter
ntEventMonDescFilter.description: The display string representation of the regular expression to match the description in the event log. Valid regular expressions are those as defined in ed(1).

ntEventMonStatus.name: ntEventMonStatus
ntEventMonStatus.description: The status of this entry. This variable is equivalent in semantics to the V2 SMI RowStatus textual-convention (see RFC 1443). A value of active(1) indicates that the agent is currently monitoring and evaluating the current row. A Value of notInService(2) indicates that the agent has suspended evaluation of the row. Setting this object to destroy(2) causes the agent to suspend evaluation of its row and free its resources. For row creation to occur, the manager must supply active(1), createAndGo(4), createAndWait(5), or notInService(2) as the value of this object. If an error occurs at any time during the processing of a particular ntEventMon Table entry, its Status column will be set to notReady(3).

ntEventMonDescr.name: ntEventMonDescr
ntEventMonDescr.description: A textual description of this entry possibly identifying the purpose of this entry and who created it.

ntEventMonAction.name: ntEventMonAction
ntEventMonAction.description: A string specifying the command to be executed upon finding a match.
